Mark--
 
thanks for this, it's very interesting.
 
Some questions:
 
The container provides the ability to specify which media type
it accepts. If this is XML, then it makes sense to use
rf:acceptedNamespace to specify which semantics the conteiner
understands. But what if the input type is not XML but some other
form of semantically structured data? Propably the addition of
a more generic element such as rf:acceptedSemantics could help here?
 
 
Is the intention behind the rf-namespace to signal that the input is
requested or possible now (at the time of parsing) or is the intention
more
to publish the availablility of rf:Containers (e.g. publishing a list
of many rf:Containers to inform 'semantic web agents') in general?
 
 
Also, rf is a fragment-identifier-free namespace. Cool! ;-)
 
Jan



Mark Baker <distobj@...> schrieb am 10.09.2003, 06:52:03:
> I'd appreciate comments on this, which is basically a way of
> communicating what HTML forms does, with RDF, and with some RESTy
> self-description voodoo (that may very well be overkill).
> 
> http://www.markbaker.ca/2003/05/RDF-Forms/
> 
> You might recognize parts of it from RestRDF, and my HTTP resource
> state model.
>
